snippet: The presence of genetic material from two other cancers in Pap smears, used to detect cervical cancer, suggests it may become possible to look for three diseases with one test.
abstract: Study in journal Science Translational Medicine finds Pap test, which has prevented countless deaths from cervical cancer, may eventually help to detect cancers of the uterus and ovaries as well; for first time, researchers have found genetic material from uterine or ovarian cancers in Pap smears, meaning it may become possible to detect three diseases with one test.
lead_paragraph: The presence of genetic material from two other cancers in Pap smears, used to detect cervical cancer, suggests it may become possible to look for three diseases with one test.

headline.seo: Pap Test May Prove Useful at Detecting More Types of Cancer, Study Suggests
headline.main: Pap Test Could Help Find Cancers of Uterus and Ovaries
headline.print_headline: Pap Test Could Be Used to Find Cancers of Uterus and Ovaries
